entry.title: üéØ Selective fine-tuning of Language Models with Spectrum
entry.content:
TIP

I‚Äôve published an extensive tutorial on Spectrum on the ü§ó Hugging Face blog. For a short intro, read on!

QLoRA

QLoRA revolutionized LLM fine-tuning in May 2023.

This method trains Low Rank Adapters on top of a quantized Language Model, drastically reducing GPU memory usage.

QLoRA made fine-tuning accessible on consumer hardware and became incredibly popular.

However, QLoRA has some limitations ‚õî

  • Lower performance compared to full fine-tuning.
  • Highly sensitive to hyperparameters (rank and alpha).
  • LoRA-trained models introduce ‚Äúintruder‚Äù dimensions, potentially misaligning them with pre-training distribution and limiting adaptability to new tasks (see LoRA vs Full Fine-tuning: An Illusion of Equivalence).

Looking for simplicity, full performance, and memory savings?

Spectrum

üéØ Spectrum is an interesting alternative.

üî¨ Analyzes weight matrices for all layers in a Language Model and calculates a Signal to Noise Ratio (SNR) for each one.

üîπ Uses Random Matrix Theory (Marchenko-Pastur distribution) to distinguish signal from noise.

üîπ Based on a chosen percentage (say, 25%), Spectrum selects the most informative layers of each type (e.g., mlp.down_proj, self_attn.o_proj, etc.).

üîπ You can then ‚ùÑÔ∏è freeze the entire model except for these selected layers üî• and focus your fine-tuning on them.

Spectrum: evaluation and results

In the paper, the authors fine-tuned Llama-3-8B and Mistral-7B-v0.1 on the airoboros-3.1 dataset using Spectrum-50 and Spectrum-25, comparing results with full fine-tuning and QLoRA.

üìä Spectrum is competitive with full fine-tuning and outperforms QLoRA on benchmark performance.

‚ö° More memory-efficient than QLoRA in distributed training. QLoRA uses less memory on a single GPU.

Several impressive Language Models have been trained using Spectrum, including Dolphin models, Llama 3.1 Storm, numerous models by VAGO Solutions‚Ä¶

üíé Spectrum helps mitigate catastrophic forgetting‚Äîas Fernando (one of the authors) puts it: ‚ÄúTraining the layers with highest SNR implies training matrices with lower compression ratio. These are more prone to learn something new without forgetting. Learn more, forget less.‚Äù

üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è My experience with Spectrum

Since my first experiments with this method, I‚Äôve found it both effective and enjoyable to work with‚ÄîI quickly became a fan. I used it to create Italian versions of Phi 3.5 Mini and Gemma 2.

Spectrum is usable out of the box with the Axolotl fine-tuning framework, but with a small effort, you can make it work with Hugging Face TRL.

üôè Great work by Eric Hartford, Lucas Atkins, Fernando Fernandes Neto, and David Golchinfar (Arcee AI + VAGO Solutions)!
